Icons

Music quiz

1. Music trivia quiz: choose the best answer. (a,b,c,d)

Pop & Rock

  1. Who was often referred to as the "fifth Beatle"?
     a.-Yoko Ono
    b.-George Martin
    c.-Brian Epstein
    d.-Linda MacCartney

  2. He was a member of Genesis, and as a solo artist he's sold over 70 million records world-wide. Who is he?
     a.-Paul Carrack
    b.-Mike Rutherford
    c.-Phil Collins
    d.-Peter Gabriel

  3. What do Jimmi Hendrix, Janis Joplin, Jim Morrison and Kurt Cobain all have in common?
     a.-They all died at the age of 27
    b.-They all died in the 60s
    c.-They all committed suicide
    d.-They were all born in Seattle

  4. Which one of the following is not the name of a Prince album?
     a.-1999
    b.-Purple Rain
    c.-Sign o' the Times
    d.-Controversial

  5. Which well-known singer-songwriter worked as a teacher before turning to music as a full-time career?
     a.-Alanis Morissette
    b.-Bob Dylan
    c.-Sting
    d.-Tracy Chapman

    Classical Music

  6. The classical period was just one musical era in what is commonly referred to as "classical music". What are the four periods in "classical music" in the correct order?
     a.-Romantic, Renaissance, Baroque, Classical
    b.-Baroque, Renaissance, Romantic, Classical
    c.-Classical, Renaissance, Baroque, Romantic
    d.-Renaissance, Baroque, Classical, Romantic

  7. Which Russian composer wrote the score for Sergey Eisenstein's film Alexander Nevsky?
     a.-Shostakovich
    b.-Stravinsky
    c.-Prokofiev
    d.-Rimsky-Korsakov

  8. In classical singing, which is the lowest male voice?
     a.-tenor
    b.-falsetto
    c.-alto
    d.-baritone

  9. Which of the following statements about Mozart is not true?
     a.-By the age of six he was an accomplished performer on three instruments
    b.-He wrote his last three symphonies—numbers 39, 40 and 41—in just six weeks
    c.-The Requiem Mass was his last completed work
    d.-He died at the age of thirty-six

  10. Who wrote the short novel on which the story for Bizet's opera Carmen is based?
     a.-Prosper Merimee
    b.-Anatole France
    c.-Pierre Choderlos de Laclos
    d.-Victor Hugo

    Jazz & Blues

  11. Django Reinhardt is considered the greatest of all jazz guitarists. What was remarkable about his career?
     a.-He was born deaf
    b.-He didn't take up the guitar until he was in his thirties
    c.-He lost the use of two fingers on his left hand when he was 18
    d.-He was blind

  12. Blues guitarist, singer and songwriter B.B. King is a living legend. But what do the initials B.B. stand for?
     a.-Blues Breaker
    b.-Blues Boy
    c.-Big Boy
    d.-Baltimore Boy

  13. In 1988 Clint Eastwood made a movie about a musician and his life called "Bird". Who was the musician?
     a.-Trumpeter Miles Davis
    b.-Saxophonist Charlie Parker
    c.-Double-bass player Charlie Mingus
    d.-Pianist Thelonius Monk

  14. "Lady Sings the Blues" is the autobiography of which female jazz vocalist?
     a.-Ella Fitzgerald
    b.-Aretha Franklin
    c.-Nina Simone
    d.-Billie Holliday

  15. Which of the following is not a type of jazz music?
     a.-Dixieland
    b.-Bebop
    c.-Free-form
    d.-Formless

    Folk & World Music

  16. The sitar was used by the Beatles. In it's own country it's a classical instrument. Where does the sitar come from?
     a.-India
    b.-China
    c.-Nepal
    d.-Afghanistan

  17. What is a hurdy-gurdy?
     a.-A Bulgarian folk singer
    b.-A type of harmonica
    c.-A mechanised fiddle
    d.-A large, tuneable drum

  18. With which folk music do you associate the uillean pipes?
     a.-Breton
    b.-Irish
    c.-Basque
    d.-Scottish

  19. What shape is the body of the Russian stringed instrument the balalaika?
     a.-square
    b.-round
    c.-It's shaped like the body of a mandolin
    d.-triangular

  20. Which African country does juju music come from?
     a.-Nigeria
    b.-Mali
    c.-Burundi
    d.-Malawi
